revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Gib Gas – Ich will Spass | image = Gib_gas_-_ich_will_spass_(DVD_cover).jpg | border = | caption = | director = Wolfgang Büld | writer = Wolfgang Büld, Georg Seitz, Peter Zemann | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Nena]] * Markus Mörl * Endrick Gerber * Peter Lengauer * [[Karl Dall]] * Cornelia Kraus * Horst Pasderski * Helga Tolle * Gernot Duda }} | producer = Georg Seitz, Hans Weth | music = [[Extrabreit]], Morgenrot, Markus Mörl, [[Nena]] | cinematography = | editing = Peter Fratzscher | studio = | distributor = | released = 3 February 1983 | runtime = 91 minutes | country = [[West Germany]] | language = German | budget = 1.2 million [[Deutsch mark]]<ref name="Pop Rocky Supplement">{{cite journal|title=Der Film von Nena|journal=Pop Rocky Staralbum|date=1983|volume=Free Supplement - "Nena"|page=7}}</ref> | gross = }} '''''Gib Gas – Ich will Spass''''' (German for "Step on the gas – I want fun") is a 1983 film which helped to launch the career of the German pop singer [[Nena]], although it took its title from the lyrics of her co-star Markus Mörl's 1982 hit single ''Ich will Spass''.<ref>Brendel p101</ref> Following the success of Nena's song "[[99 Luftballons]]" (which is not featured in the film), it was dubbed into English and released in the USA under the title ''Hangin' out''.
==Plot==
A youthful student Robby (Markus Mörl) joins his new classmates in a Munich school, where he meets the extrovert Tina ([[Nena]]) and falls in love with her. Tina, however, only has eyes for Tino (Endrick Gerber), an unemployed womanizer who works on a fairground. While Robby tries in vain to conquer Tina's heart, she already has other plans: she wants to drop out of school and run away with Tino. Tino, however, drives off without Tina. In order to quickly catch him up, Tina, without explaining her motives, charms Robby to "step on the gas" and on Robby's scooter, Tina and Robby give chase. Over the course of their pursuit they come to like each other more and more.
In an old hut they finally kiss, and Tina realises that she has fallen in love with Robby. At the same time, however, Robby finally becomes aware that they have only been driving around in pursuit of Tino and leaves. Tina finds Robby on the train to Venice, where the finale is set. In Venice Tina doesn't want anything to do with Tino, who falls into the water and Robby goes to his rescue. Neither can swim, however, and so Tino is pulled out by a girl on a passing boat whilst Tina saves Robby.
==Music==
''Gib Gas – Ich will Spass'' showcases the music of its two main stars, Nena and Markus Mörl, who had an affair during the course of the making of the film.<ref name="Brendel">{{cite book|last1=Brendel|first1=Rolf|title=Geschichte einer Band|date=2014|publisher=Aufbau Verlag GmbH & Co. KG|location=Berlin|isbn=9783351050153|page=102}}</ref>
The film features 6 tracks by Nena's [[Nena (band)|eponymous band]],<ref name="Nena website">{{cite web|title=Diskografie - Gib Gas - Ich will Spass|url=http://www.nena.de/de/discografie/gib-gas-–-ich-will-spass|website=Nena.de|accessdate=3 September 2016}}</ref> including their first German release and breakthrough hit "[[Nena (album)#"Nur geträumt"|Nur geträumt]]" (1982), its B-side "Ganz oben" and "[[Nena (album)#"Leuchtturm"|Leuchtturm]]" which went on to become a top 10 hit in Germany on two separate occasions (1983 and 2003).<ref name="German charts - Nena">{{cite web|title=Official German Charts|url=https://www.offiziellecharts.de/suche|website=offiziellecharts.de|publisher=GfK Entertainment|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref>
The film also includes Nena and Markus's "exclusive" version of his German top 5 hit "Kleine Taschenlampe brenn'",<ref name="Nena website" /> the female sections of which were sung in the original by Andrea-Maria Schneider. Markus and Nena performed the song live at the 2002 concert marking 20 years since the release of "Nur geträumt"<ref>{{cite web|title=Diskografie - Nena feat. Nena live|url=http://www.nena.de/de/discografie/nena-feat-nena-live-0|website=Nena.de|accessdate=3 September 2016}}</ref>
==Reviews==
Contemporary reviews of the film were damning.
In ''[[Der Tagesspiegel]]'' Carla Rhode wrote, "I would also have liked to have had fun but all that stayed with me were Nena and Markus and the director Wolfgang Büld being completely guilty of a lame entertainment dud. What was it meant to be? A story about runaways, a hit movie or just a few fairly unimaginative scenes to somehow accommodate a handful of numbers by Nena and Markus?"<ref name="Hobsch book">{{cite book|last1=Hobsch|first1=Manfred|title=Liebe, Tanz und 1000 Schlagerflme|date=1998|publisher=Schwarzkopf & Schwarzkopf|isbn=3896021664|page=209}}<!--|accessdate=8 June 2015--></ref>
For the ''[[Berliner Morgenpost]]'' Peter Müller wrote, "The film material was not new, only the times different, the context changing. And so Wolfgang Büld's ''Gib Gas – Ich will Spass'' could have been filmed twenty years ago, perhaps with [[Peter Alexander (Austrian performer)|Peter Alexander]] and [[Cornelia Froboess]] singing 'In love, engaged, married'. This little movie is of unqualified irrelevance."<ref name="Hobsch book" />
And no more complimentary was Otto Heuer, in the ''[[Rheinische Post]]'', opining, "And now that five and twenty years in the life of pop industry insights have passed, this attempt at a revival of that now blissfully transfigured genre turns out to have been convincingly stillborn."<ref name="Hobsch book" />
Nevertheless, the film was a box office success in Germany where 256,000 people saw it during its first four weeks of release.<ref name="Pop Rocky Supplement" /> It finished as the 13th most successful film in Germany in 1983 with in excess of 1.5 million people seeing it.<ref>{{cite web|title=Top 100 Deutschland 1983|url=http://www.insidekino.com/DJahr/D1983.htm|website=insidekino.com|accessdate=16 May 2018}}</ref> However Nena very quickly distanced herself from the movie. In a May 1984 interview with ''[[New Musical Express]]'', at the peak of her international fame from the global success of "99 Luftballons", she said, "Don't talk about this fucking film. I hate it – it follows me wherever we go."<ref name="NME 5/5/84">{{cite journal|title=Nena - the girl from C&A|journal=New Musical Express|date=5 May 1984|page=28|accessdate=}}</ref> In another interview at the same time, Nena explained that she, "thought it would be a good thing to make our music a little popular 'cause at the time we weren't successful at all. So I did it, and the result was that we made this movie successful, and not the other way."<ref>{{cite web|title=30 Years Ago: Nena of "99 Luftballoons" fame on the phone from Berlin|url=http://earofnewt.com/2014/05/18/30-years-ago-nena-of-99-luftballoons-fame-on-the-phone-from-berlin/|website=earofnewt.com|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref>
